content: The question arose in #29878 (see the unresolved conversation there). Given XXX and YYY two measurable spaces and μ\muμ a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure on the product space X×YX \times YX×Y, is μ\muμ uniquely determined by its value on measurable rectangles (i.e. sets of the form s×ts \times ts×t when sss is a measurable subset of XXX and ttt is a measurable subset of YYY)? The answer is yes if μ\muμ is finite, as Rémy proves in #29878. The answer is also yes if μ\muμ is the product of two σ\sigmaσ-finite measures. But I was not able to answer the question for a general σ\sigmaσ-finite measure. One way to prove it would be to show that if μ\muμ is a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure on X×YX \times YX×Y then one can always find sequences (Xn)(X_n)(Xn​) and (Yn)(Y_n)(Yn​) of measurable spanning subsets of XXX and YYY respectively such that for all nnn, μ(Xn×Yn)\mu(X_n \times Y_n)μ(Xn​×Yn​) is finite, but that does not seem obvious. I don't really have an intuition as to whether the answer is yes or no. Any thoughts?

The answer is no. The following counterexample is essentially in Halmos.

I will construct a measurable function BBB from R2\R^2R2 to [0,+∞)[0, +\infty)[0,+∞) whose integral over any rectangle E×FE \times FE×F (where EEE and FFF are measurable sets with positive Lebesgue measure) is infinite. Then the measure with density BBB can not be distinguished using only rectangles from another different measure coming from the same construction. And still it is sigma-finite, as BBB is finite evyerwhere.

I will first construct a function A:R→RA : \R \to \RA:R→R. Let rnr_nrn​ be a dense sequence of rationals and let InI_nIn​ be the interval centered at rnr_nrn​ of length 2−n2^{-n}2−n. Set A(x)=∑n4n1In(x)A(x) = \sum_n 4^n 1_{I_n}(x)A(x)=∑n​4n1In​​(x). As the sum of the lengths of InI_nIn​ is finite, the function AAA is finite almost everywhere (by Borel-Cantelli, it's a finite sum).

Let B(x,y)=A(x−y)B(x,y) = A(x-y)B(x,y)=A(x−y). I claim it works. I have to check that ∫E×FB=∞\int_{E \times F} B = \infty∫E×F​B=∞ whenever E,FE,FE,F have positive measure. This follows from the fact that given two sets with positive measure, their difference contains an interval, and therefore one of the sets InI_nIn​ with nnn arbitrarily large. And moreover points in InI_nIn​ can be written as differences of points in EEE and FFF in many ways (more precisely with a measure control), which means that one will be able to bound below ∫E×FB\int_{E\times F} B∫E×F​B by 2−1∫InA2^{-1} \int_{I_n} A2−1∫In​​A, say. As the latter integral is 2n2^n2n, we're done.

(To write down precisely the argument, one can use a Lebesgue density point argument to assume that EEE and FFF are contained in two intervals and cover 99% of them. The details are a little bit too tedious to be posted here, but they're not hard with the above sketch).
Thanks for the answer and the detailed example!

Thank you very much! I had a bit of "fun" writing down all the details. I get something smaller than the one half in front of the integral at the end, so maybe you had something better in mind.

Antoine Chambert-Loir said:

I failed at locating that result in Halmos's book. Do you have an idea about where it should be?

The closest I found was exercise 7 on page 183 at the end of chapter VIII, although it's not quite the same thing.

It's in Problems for Mathematicians, Young and Old, Problem 14E. Well, the problem is not exactly the same, but very closely related, and the solution is full of typos (and plainly wrong at the end), but the main idea is there and it is enough to fill the gaps.
Oh I understand why I did not find it in his Measure Theory book then :laughing:
Well technically you did not specify the location but I assumed that it was Measure Theory.
I also thought it was Measure Theory, before checking :-)
The morale is that to compare two measures, one needs to have a generating sets of the sigma-algebra which consists of sets of finite measures for both of them and at which they agree.

Geometrically, the example is nice, but disturbing, because I don't understand how the change of variables f ⁣:(x,y)↦(x+y,x−y)f\colon (x,y)\mapsto (x+y,x-y)f:(x,y)↦(x+y,x−y) could transform a measure into a measure which is so much unrelated.

I wouldn't say it transforms the measure into something very unrelated. The thing is that the initial measure is already very nasty: the measure with density A is sigma-finite on the real line, but gives infinite mass to every interval.

Antoine Chambert-Loir said:

The morale is that to compare two measures, one needs to have a generating sets of the sigma-algebra which consists of sets of finite measures for both of them and at which they agree.

To me the question was rather whether these sets of finite measure could always be picked to be mesurable rectangles on a product space.
